pageContext.claim: “And they started blaming all sorts of people: [George] Papadopoulos, who nobody knew, and Carter Page, who I actually feel very sorry for. I never met them. … Even though I didn't meet Carter Page and Papadopoulos I actually sat at a table with him for about 15 minutes and that was it. I never spoke to him or anything.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump plays down his connection to former campaign aides Papadopoulos and Page. In a March 2016 meeting with The Washington Post editorial board, Page was the first person Trump mentioned when asked about his foreign policy team. Papadopoulos was the second. Weeks after that interview, Trump met with various advisers including Papadopoulos. He claims not to remember what was said. "In the meeting, according to court documents, Papadopoulos touted his connections to Russia in front of Trump and [Jeff] Sessions and offered to arrange a meeting between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin," The Post reported. "J.D. Gordon, a Trump adviser who attended the meeting, recalled in an interview with The Washington Post that after Papadopoulos said he could introduce Trump to Putin, Sessions 'shut him down.'" Page has said he was in meetings with Trump but never spoke with him. "I've certainly been in a number of meetings with him and I've learned a tremendous amount from him," he said in a news conference in Moscow in 2016. Two years later, Page told ABC News that he had never spoken with Trump.
